poems.one: Wake! For the Sun, who scatter’d into flight
poems.two: The Stars before him from the Field of Night,
poems.three: Drives Night along with them from Heav'n, and strikes
poems.four: The Sultan’s Turret with a Shaft of Light.

poems.one: Before the phantom of False morning died,
poems.two: Methought a Voice within the Tavern cried,
poems.three: “When all the Temple is prepared within,
poems.four: Why nods the drowsy Worshipper outside?”

poems.one: And, as the Cock crew, those who stood before
poems.two: The Tavern shouted–“Open then the Door!
poems.three: You know how little while we have to stay,
poems.four: And, once departed, may return no more.”

poems.one: Now the New Year reviving old Desires,
poems.two: The thoughtful Soul to Solitude retires,
poems.three: Where the White Hand Of Moses on the Bough
poems.four: Puts out, and Jesus from the Ground suspires.

poems.one: Iram indeed is gone with all his Rose,
poems.two: And Jamshyd’s Sev'n-ring’d Cup where no one knows;
poems.three: But still a Ruby kindles in the Vine,
poems.four: And many a Garden by the Water blows,

poems.one: And David’s lips are lockt; but in divine
poems.two: High-piping Pehlevi, with “Wine! Wine! Wine!
poems.three: Red Wine!”–the Nightingale cries to the Rose
poems.four: That sallow cheek of hers t' incarnadine.

poems.one: Come, fill the Cup, and in the fire of Spring
poems.two: Your Winter-garment of Repentance fling:
poems.three: The Bird of Time has but a little way
poems.four: To flutter–and the Bird is on the Wing.

poems.one: Whether at Naishapur or Babylon,
poems.two: Whether the Cup with sweet or bitter run,
poems.three: The Wine of Life keeps oozing drop by drop,
poems.four: The Leaves of Life keep falling one by one.

poems.one: Each Morn a thousand Roses brings, you say;
poems.two: Yes, but where leaves the Rose of Yesterday?
poems.three: And this first Summer month that brings the Rose
poems.four: Shall take Jamshyd and Kaikobad away.

poems.one: Well, let it take them! What have we to do
poems.two: With Kaikobad the Great, or Kaikhosru?
poems.three: Let Zal and Rustum bluster as they will,
poems.four: Or Hatim call to Supper–heed not you

poems.one: With me along the strip of Herbage strown
poems.two: That just divides the desert from the sown,
poems.three: Where name of Slave and Sultan is forgot–
poems.four: And Peace to Mahmud on his golden Throne!

poems.one: A Book of Verses underneath the Bough,
poems.two: A Jug of Wine, a Loaf of Bread–and Thou
poems.three: Beside me singing in the Wilderness–
poems.four: Oh, Wilderness were Paradise enow!

poems.one: Some for the Glories of This World; and some
poems.two: Sigh for the Prophet’s Paradise to come;
poems.three: Ah, take the Cash, and let the Credit go,
poems.four: Nor heed the rumble of a distant Drum!

poems.one: Look to the blowing Rose about us–“Lo,
poems.two: Laughing,” she says, “into the world I blow,
poems.three: At once the silken tassel of my Purse
poems.four: Tear, and its Treasure on the Garden throw.”

poems.one: And those who husbanded the Golden grain,
poems.two: And those who flung it to the winds like Rain,
poems.three: Alike to no such aureate Earth are turn’d
poems.four: As, buried once, Men want dug up again.

poems.one: The Worldly Hope men set their Hearts upon
poems.two: Turns Ashes–or it prospers; and anon,
poems.three: Like Snow upon the Desert’s dusty Face,
poems.four: Lighting a little hour or two–is gone.

poems.one: Think, in this batter’d Caravanserai
poems.two: Whose Portals are alternate Night and Day,
poems.three: How Sultan after Sultan with his Pomp
poems.four: Abode his destined Hour, and went his way.

poems.one: They say the Lion and the Lizard keep
poems.two: The Courts where Jamshyd gloried and drank deep:
poems.three: And Bahram, that great Hunter–the Wild Ass
poems.four: Stamps o'er his Head, but cannot break his Sleep.

poems.one: I sometimes think that never blows so red
poems.two: The Rose as where some buried Caesar bled;
poems.three: That every Hyacinth the Garden wears
poems.four: Dropt in her Lap from some once lovely Head.

poems.one: And this reviving Herb whose tender Green
poems.two: Fledges the River-Lip on which we lean–
poems.three: Ah, lean upon it lightly! for who knows
poems.four: From what once lovely Lip it springs unseen!

poems.one: Ah, my Belov'ed fill the Cup that clears
poems.two: To-day Past Regrets and Future Fears:
poems.three: To-morrow!–Why, To-morrow I may be
poems.four: Myself with Yesterday’s Sev'n Thousand Years.

poems.one: For some we loved, the loveliest and the best
poems.two: That from his Vintage rolling Time hath prest,
poems.three: Have drunk their Cup a Round or two before,
poems.four: And one by one crept silently to rest.

poems.one: And we, that now make merry in the Room
poems.two: They left, and Summer dresses in new bloom
poems.three: Ourselves must we beneath the Couch of Earth
poems.four: Descend–ourselves to make a Couch–for whom?

poems.one: Ah, make the most of what we yet may spend,
poems.two: Before we too into the Dust descend;
poems.three: Dust into Dust, and under Dust to lie
poems.four: Sans Wine, sans Song, sans Singer, and–sans End!

poems.one: Alike for those who for To-day prepare,
poems.two: And those that after some To-morrow stare,
poems.three: A Muezzin from the Tower of Darkness cries
poems.four: “Fools! your Reward is neither Here nor There.”

poems.one: Why, all the Saints and Sages who discuss’d
poems.two: Of the Two Worlds so wisely–they are thrust
poems.three: Like foolish Prophets forth; their Words to Scorn
poems.four: Are scatter’d, and their Mouths are stopt with Dust.

poems.one: Myself when young did eagerly frequent
poems.two: Doctor and Saint, and heard great argument
poems.three: About it and about: but evermore
poems.four: Came out by the same door where in I went.

poems.one: With them the seed of Wisdom did I sow,
poems.two: And with mine own hand wrought to make it grow;
poems.three: And this was all the Harvest that I reap’d–
poems.four: “I came like Water, and like Wind I go.”

poems.one: Into this Universe, and Why not knowing
poems.two: Nor Whence, like Water willy-nilly flowing;
poems.three: And out of it, as Wind along the Waste,
poems.four: I know not Whither, willy-nilly blowing.

poems.one: What, without asking, hither hurried Whence?
poems.two: And, without asking, Whither hurried hence!
poems.three: Oh, many a Cup of this forbidden Wine
poems.four: Must drown the memory of that insolence!

poems.one: Up from Earth’s Centre through the Seventh Gate
poems.two: rose, and on the Throne of Saturn sate;
poems.three: And many a Knot unravel’d by the Road;
poems.four: But not the Master-knot of Human Fate.

poems.one: There was the Door to which I found no Key;
poems.two: There was the Veil through which I might not see:
poems.three: Some little talk awhile of Me and Thee
poems.four: There was–and then no more of Thee and Me.

poems.one: Earth could not answer; nor the Seas that mourn
poems.two: In flowing Purple, of their Lord forlorn;
poems.three: Nor rolling Heaven, with all his Signs reveal’d
poems.four: And hidden by the sleeve of Night and Morn.

poems.one: Then of the Thee in Me works behind
poems.two: The Veil, I lifted up my hands to find
poems.three: A Lamp amid the Darkness; and I heard,
poems.four: As from Without–“The Me Within Thee Blind!”

poems.one: Then to the lip of this poor earthen Urn
poems.two: I lean’d, the Secret of my Life to learn:
poems.three: And Lip to Lip it murmur’d–“While you live
poems.four: Drink!–for, once dead, you never shall return.”

poems.one: I think the Vessel, that with fugitive
poems.two: Articulation answer’d, once did live,
poems.three: And drink; and Ah! the passive Lip I kiss’d,
poems.four: How many Kisses might it take–and give!

poems.one: For I remember stopping by the way
poems.two: To watch a Potter thumping his wet Clay:
poems.three: And with its all-obliterated Tongue
poems.four: It murmur’d–“Gently, Brother, gently, pray!”

poems.one: And has not such a Story from of Old
poems.two: Down Man’s successive generations roll’d
poems.three: Of such a clod of saturated Earth
poems.four: Cast by the Maker into Human mould?

poems.one: And not a drop that from our Cups we throw
poems.two: For Earth to drink of, but may steal below
poems.three: To quench the fire of Anguish in some Eye
poems.four: There hidden–far beneath, and long ago.

poems.one: As then the Tulip for her morning sup
poems.two: Of Heav'nly Vintage from the soil looks up,
poems.three: Do you devoutly do the like, till Heav'n
poems.four: To Earth invert you–like an empty Cup.

poems.one: Perplext no more with Human or Divine,
poems.two: To-morrow’s tangle to the winds resign,
poems.three: And lose your fingers in the tresses of
poems.four: The Cypress–slender Minister of Wine.

poems.one: And if the Wine you drink, the Lip you press
poems.two: End in what All begins and ends in–Yes;
poems.three: Think then you are To-day what Yesterday
poems.four: You were–To-morrow You shall not be less.

poems.one: So when that Angel of the darker Drink
poems.two: At last shall find you by the river-brink,
poems.three: And, offering his Cup, invite your Soul
poems.four: Forth to your Lips to quaff–you shall not shrink.

poems.one: Why, if the Soul can fling the Dust aside,
poems.two: And naked on the Air of Heaven ride,
poems.three: Were’t not a Shame–were’t not a Shame for him
poems.four: In this clay carcase crippled to abide?

poems.one: ‘Tis but a Tent where takes his one day’s rest
poems.two: A Sultan to the realm of Death addrest;
poems.three: The Sultan rises, and the dark Ferrash
poems.four: Strikes, and prepares it for another Guest.

poems.one: And fear not lest Existence closing your
poems.two: Account, and mine, should know the like no more;
poems.three: The Eternal Saki from that Bowl has pour’d
poems.four: Millions of Bubbles like us, and will pour.

poems.one: When You and I behind the Veil are past,
poems.two: Oh, but the long, long while the World shall last,
poems.three: Which of our Coming and Departure heeds
poems.four: As the Sea’s self should heed a pebble-cast.

poems.one: A Moment’s Halt–a momentary taste
poems.two: Of Being from the Well amid the Waste–
poems.three: And Lo!–the phantom Caravan has reach’d
poems.four: The Nothing it set out from–Oh, make haste!

poems.one: Would you that spangle of Existence spend
poems.two: About the Secret–Quick about it, Friend!
poems.three: A Hair perhaps divides the False and True–
poems.four: And upon what, prithee, may life depend?

poems.one: A Hair perhaps divides the False and True;
poems.two: Yes; and a single Alif were the clue–
poems.three: Could you but find it–to the Treasure-house,
poems.four: And peradventure to The Master too;

poems.one: Whose secret Presence, through Creation’s veins
poems.two: Running Quicksilver-like eludes your pains;
poems.three: Taking all shapes from Mah to Mahi; and
poems.four: They change and perish all–but He remains;

poems.one: A moment guess’d–then back behind the Fold
poems.two: Immerst of Darkness round the Drama roll’d
poems.three: Which, for the Pastime of Eternity,
poems.four: He doth Himself contrive, enact, behold.

poems.one: But if in vain, down on the stubborn floor
poems.two: Of Earth, and up to Heav'n’s unopening Door
poems.three: You gaze To-day, while You are You–how then
poems.four: To-morrow, You when shall be You no more?

poems.one: Waste not your Hour, nor in the vain pursuit
poems.two: Of This and That endeavour and dispute;
poems.three: Better be jocund with the fruitful Grape
poems.four: Than sadden after none, or bitter, Fruit.

poems.one: You know, my Friends, with what a brave Carouse
poems.two: I made a Second Marriage in my house;
poems.three: Divorced old barren Reason from my Bed
poems.four: And took the Daughter of the Vine to Spouse.

poems.one: For “Is” and “Is-not” though with Rule and Line
poems.two: And “Up” and “Down” by Logic I define,
poems.three: Of all that one should care to fathom,
poems.four: Was never deep in anything but–Wine.

poems.one: Ah, but my Computations, People say,
poems.two: Reduced the Year to better reckoning?–Nay
poems.three: 'Twas only striking from the Calendar
poems.four: Unborn To-morrow, and dead Yesterday.

poems.one: And lately, by the Tavern Door agape,
poems.two: Came shining through the Dusk an Angel Shape
poems.three: Bearing a Vessel on his Shoulder; and
poems.four: He bid me taste of it; and 'twas–the Grape!

poems.one: The Grape that can with Logic absolute
poems.two: The Two-and-Seventy jarring Sects confute:
poems.three: The sovereign Alchemist that in a trice
poems.four: Life’s leaden metal into Gold transmute:

poems.one: The mighty Mahmud, Allah-breathing Lord
poems.two: That all the misbelieving and black Horde
poems.three: Of Fears and Sorrows that infest the Soul
poems.four: Scatters before him with his whirlwind Sword.

poems.one: Why, be this Juice the growth of God, who dare
poems.two: Blaspheme the twisted tendril as a Snare?
poems.three: A Blessing, we should use it, should we not?
poems.four: And if a Curse–why, then, Who set it there?

poems.one: I must abjure the Balm of Life, I must,
poems.two: Scared by some After-reckoning ta'en on trust,
poems.three: Or lured with Hope of some Diviner Drink,
poems.four: To fill the Cup–when crumbled into Dust!

poems.one: Oh, threats of Hell and Hopes of Paradise!
poems.two: One thing at least is certain–This Life flies;
poems.three: One thing is certain and the rest is Lies;
poems.four: The Flower that once has blown for ever dies.

poems.one: Strange, is it not? that of the myriads who
poems.two: Before us pass’d the door of Darkness through,
poems.three: Not one returns to tell us of the Road,
poems.four: Which to discover we must travel too.

poems.one: The Revelations of Devout and Learn’d
poems.two: Who rose before us, and as Prophets burn’d,
poems.three: Are all but Stories, which, awoke from Sleep,
poems.four: They told their comrades, and to Sleep return’d.

poems.one: I sent my Soul through the Invisible,
poems.two: Some letter of that After-life to spell:
poems.three: And by and by my Soul return’d to me,
poems.four: And answer’d “I Myself am Heav'n and Hell:”

poems.one: Heav'n but the Vision of fulfill’d Desire,
poems.two: And Hell the Shadow from a Soul on fire,
poems.three: Cast on the Darkness into which Ourselves,
poems.four: So late emerged from, shall so soon expire.

poems.one: We are no other than a moving row
poems.two: Of Magic Shadow-shapes that come and go
poems.three: Round with the Sun-illumined Lantern held
poems.four: In Midnight by the Master of the Show;

poems.one: But helpless Pieces of the Game He plays
poems.two: Upon this Chequer-board of Nights and Days;
poems.three: Hither and thither moves, and checks, and slays,
poems.four: And one by one back in the Closet lays.

poems.one: The Ball no question makes of Ayes and Noes,
poems.two: But Here or There as strikes the Player goes;
poems.three: And He that toss’d you down into the Field,
poems.four: He knows about it all–He knows–HE knows!

poems.one: The Ball no question makes of Ayes and Noes,
poems.two: But Here or There as strikes the Player goes;
poems.three: And He that toss’d you down into the Field,
poems.four: He knows about it all–He knows–HE knows!

poems.one: And that inverted Bowl they call the Sky,
poems.two: Whereunder crawling coop’d we live and die,
poems.three: Lift not your hands to It for help–for It
poems.four: As impotently moves as you or I.

poems.one: With Earth’s first Clay They did the Last Man knead,
poems.two: And there of the Last Harvest sow’d the Seed:
poems.three: And the first Morning of Creation wrote
poems.four: What the Last Dawn of Reckoning shall read.

poems.one: Yesterday This Day’s Madness did prepare;
poems.two: To-morrow’s Silence, Triumph, or Despair:
poems.three: Drink! for you know not whence you came, nor why:
poems.four: Drink! for you know not why you go, nor where.

poems.one: I tell you this–When, started from the Goal,
poems.two: Over the flaming shoulders of the Foal
poems.three: Of Heav'n Parwin and Mushtari they flung
poems.four: In my predestined Plot of Dust and Soul.

poems.one: The Vine had struck a fibre: which about
poems.two: If clings my being–let the Dervish flout;
poems.three: Of my Base metal may be filed a Key,
poems.four: That shall unlock the Door he howls without.

poems.one: And this I know: whether the one True Light
poems.two: Kindle to Love, or Wrath-consume me quite,
poems.three: One Flash of It within the Tavern caught
poems.four: Better than in the Temple lost outright.

poems.one: What! out of senseless Nothing to provoke
poems.two: A conscious Something to resent the yoke
poems.three: Of unpermitted Pleasure, under pain
poems.four: Of Everlasting Penalties, if broke!

poems.one: What! from his helpless Creature be repaid
poems.two: Pure Gold for what he lent him dross-allay’d–
poems.three: Sue for a Debt he never did contract,
poems.four: And cannot answer–Oh, the sorry trade!

poems.one: Oh, Thou, who didst with pitfall and with gin
poems.two: Beset the Road I was to wander in,
poems.three: Thou wilt not with Predestined Evil round
poems.four: Enmesh, and then impute my Fall to Sin!

poems.one: Oh, Thou who Man of baser Earth didst make,
poems.two: And ev'n with Paradise devise the Snake:
poems.three: For all the Sin wherewith the Face of Man
poems.four: Is blacken’d–Man’s forgiveness give–and take!

poems.one: As under cover of departing Day
poems.two: Slunk hunger-stricken Ramazan away,
poems.three: Once more within the Potter’s house alone
poems.four: I stood, surrounded by the Shapes of Clay.

poems.one: Shapes of all Sorts and Sizes, great and small,
poems.two: That stood along the floor and by the wall;
poems.three: And some loquacious Vessels were; and some
poems.four: Listen’d perhaps, but never talk’d at all.

poems.one: Said one among them–“Surely not in vain
poems.two: My substance of the common Earth was ta'en
poems.three: And to this Figure moulded, to be broke,
poems.four: Or trampled back to shapeless Earth again.”

poems.one: Then said a Second–“Ne'er a peevish Boy
poems.two: Would break the Bowl from which he drank in joy,
poems.three: And He that with his hand the Vessel made
poems.four: Will surely not in after Wrath destroy.”

poems.one: After a momentary silence spake
poems.two: Some Vessel of a more ungainly Make;
poems.three: “They sneer at me for leaning all awry:
poems.four: What! did the Hand then of the Potter shake?”

poems.one: Whereat some one of the loquacious Lot–
poems.two: I think a Sufi pipkin-waxing hot–
poems.three: “All this of Pot and Potter–Tell me then,
poems.four: Who is the Potter, pray, and who the Pot?”

poems.one: “Why,” said another, “Some there are who tell
poems.two: Of one who threatens he will toss to Hell
poems.three: The luckless Pots he marr’d in making–Pish!
poems.four: He’s a Good Fellow, and 'twill all be well.”

poems.one: “Well,” Murmur’d one, “Let whoso make or buy,
poems.two: My Clay with long Oblivion is gone dry:
poems.three: But fill me with the old familiar juice,
poems.four: Methinks I might recover by and by.”

poems.one: So while the Vessels one by one were speaking,
poems.two: The little Moon look’d in that all were seeking:
poems.three: And then they jogg’d each other, “Brother! Brother!
poems.four: Now for the Porter’s shoulder-knot a-creaking!”

poems.one: Ah, with the Grape my fading Life provide,
poems.two: And wash the Body whence the Life has died,
poems.three: And lay me, shrouded in the living Leaf,
poems.four: By some not unfrequented Garden-side.

poems.one: That ev'n my buried Ashes such a snare
poems.two: Of Vintage shall fling up into the Air
poems.three: As not a True-believer passing by
poems.four: But shall be overtaken unaware.

poems.one: Indeed the Idols I have loved so long
poems.two: Have done my credit in this World much wrong:
poems.three: Have drown’d my Glory in a shallow Cup
poems.four: And sold my Reputation for a Song.

poems.one: Indeed, indeed, Repentance of before
poems.two: I swore–but was I sober when I swore?
poems.three: And then and then came Spring, and Rose-in-hand
poems.four: My thread-bare Penitence apieces tore.

poems.one: And much as Wine has play’d the Infidel,
poems.two: And robb’d me of my Robe of Honour–Well,
poems.three: I wonder often what the Vintners buy
poems.four: One half so precious as the stuff they sell.

poems.one: Yet Ah, that Spring should vanish with the Rose!
poems.two: That Youth’s sweet-scented manuscript should close!
poems.three: The Nightingale that in the branches sang,
poems.four: Ah, whence, and whither flown again, who knows!

poems.one: Would but the Desert of the Fountain yield
poems.two: One glimpse–if dimly, yet indeed, reveal’d,
poems.three: To which the fainting Traveller might spring,
poems.four: As springs the trampled herbage of the field!

poems.one: Would but some wing'ed Angel ere too late
poems.two: Arrest the yet unfolded Roll of Fate,
poems.three: And make the stern Recorder otherwise
poems.four: Enregister, or quite obliterate!

poems.one: Ah, Love! could you and I with Him conspire
poems.two: To grasp this sorry Scheme of Things entire,
poems.three: Would not we shatter it to bits–and then
poems.four: Re-mould it nearer to the Heart’s Desire!

poems.one: Yon rising Moon that looks for us again–
poems.two: How oft hereafter will she wax and wane;
poems.three: How oft hereafter rising look for us
poems.four: Through this same Garden–and for one in vain!

poems.one: And when like her, oh, Saki, you shall pass
poems.two: Among the Guests Star-scatter’d on the Grass,
poems.three: And in your joyous errand reach the spot
poems.four: Where I made One–turn down an empty Glass!
